title: Iskra Lawrence oozes glamour as she receives honorary gold medal at Trinity College Dublin
text:
She is famed for her no holds barred stance on promoting body confidence.

And Iskra Lawrence looked radiant as she received an honorary gold medal from Trinity College Dublin's University Philosophical Society on Thursday.

The model, 29, cut a stylish figure in a pink jumpsuit with a cut out at the middle and a pleated detail.

Honoured: Iskra Lawrence, 29, looked radiant as she received an Honorary Gold Medal from Trinity College Dublin's Philosophical Society on Thursday

She added height to her frame with a pair of nude heels and also sported a white blazer.

Letting her blonde locks fall loose down her shoulders, Iskra completed her look for the day with a gold necklace and matching earrings.

Iskra was invited by the university society to speak on her career in the fashion industry as well as breaking the mold as a plus-size model.

The model's body positive outlook has won her legions of fans and she currently boasts 4.5million followers on Instagram.

Fashion: The model cut a stylish figure in a pink off the shoulder jumpsuit with a cut-out at the middle and a pleated detail

Outfit: She added height to her frame with a pair of nude heels and also sported a white coat

Style: Letting her blonde locks fall loose down her shoulders, Iskra completed her look for the day with a gold necklace and matching earrings

In demand: The model's body-positive outlook has won her legions of fans and she currently boasts 4.5million followers on Instagram

Event: Iskra spoke about her career in the fashion industry as well as breaking the mold as a plus-size model (pictured with The Phil Society chair Ryan Grunwell)

Her outing comes after Glamour named her as one of the new 'shakers' in the modelling industry alongside Alessandra Garcia-Lorido, Yvonne Simone, Solange van Doorn and Seynabou Cissé.

Speaking to the publication, the American Eagle Outfitters model regretted that plus-size women were often more further sexualised than others.

She also expressed that body positivity campaigns still tended to cater to the smaller end of the plus-size spectrum.

'I can’t promise you that you’re [always] going to feel represented...So I want people to know if you can’t see yourself, you can still be it, you can still do it,' she said

'You might need to be that representation,' she added.
